title: Jaylen Brown continues to shine as Celtics hold off furious 76ers run, win third straight: 9 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Jaylen Brown scored 32 points on 13-for-19 shooting as the Celtics narrowly defeated the 76ers 109-108.
The Celtics claimed their third consecutive win and improved to .500 for the first time this season.
Despite a late comeback by the 76ers, Celtics held on defensively, forcing Embiid to miss a potential game-winning shot.

title: Julia Fox defends controversial Jackie O. Halloween costume
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Actress Julia Fox wore a controversial Halloween costume similar to Jackie Kennedy's bloodied pink suit from JFK's assassination day.
Jack Schlossberg criticized Fox's costume, calling it "disgusting, desperate and dangerous" for glorifying political violence.
Fox defended the costume as a statement on trauma and power, referencing Jackie Kennedy's decision not to change clothes after JFK's assassination.

title: Falcons QB Michael Penix Jr., WR Drake London set to play vs. Patriots
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Falcons QB Michael Penix Jr. and WR Drake London will play against the Patriots after missing last week due to injuries.
Penix (knee) and London (hip) participated fully in practice Friday after being limited earlier in the week.
The Falcons, at 3-4, face a 6-2 Patriots team on a five-game win streak in Week 9 in Foxborough.

title: Craig Breslow believes Red Sox are in ‘improved position’ to get ‘right players’ this offseason
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Craig Breslow is optimistic about the Red Sox's ability to acquire key players after a postseason appearance in 2025.
Red Sox face offseason decisions with Alex Bregman, Lucas Giolito, and Trevor Story potentially leaving, affecting roster construction.
Boston is $25 million under the luxury tax and boasts a strong farm system, providing resources to improve the team.

title: Mike Vrabel says recent Patriots changes have nothing to do with wanting to separate from the past
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Mike Vrabel insists Patriots' recent changes aren't to escape past traditions, aiming instead to improve team dynamics.
The team introduced offensive starters individually before their Week 8 game, ending a 24-year team introduction tradition.
Vrabel's adjustments include discarding past slogans, with the Patriots currently leading the AFC East at a 6-2 record.

title: Bruins’ Elias Lindholm will miss ‘a few weeks’, Khusnutdinov promoted to 1C
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Elias Lindholm will miss several weeks with a lower-body injury after a collision in the Bruins' game against the Sabres.
Bruins coach Marco Sturm confirmed Elias Lindholm's absence and announced Marat Khusnutdinov as the new top-line center.
Marat Khusnutdinov helped secure an overtime win against Buffalo, scoring the game-winning goal as the new first-line center.

title: Photos: The best moments from Salem on Halloween 2025
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Salem, Massachusetts, was filled with tourists and locals in costumes celebrating Halloween on Essex Street and other popular locations.
Popular Halloween attractions included the Haunted Happenings Marketplace, Rockafellas Restaurant, and the Salem Witch Trials Memorial.
Crowds participated in festive activities like posing for photos, visiting historic sites, and enjoying street performances and markets.

title: Moulton, without proof, accuses Trump of abusing girls with Epstein in tense TV interview
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Rep. Seth Moulton accused President Donald Trump of abusing young girls with Jeffrey Epstein during an MSNBC interview.
Moulton, a 2026 Senate candidate, provided no proof for the allegations against Trump, causing tension with host Joe Scarborough.
Scarborough challenged Moulton's claims, emphasizing the lack of evidence and the importance of factual political discourse.

title: Brian Walshe’s next court appearance scheduled as cellphone evidence remains accessible
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Brian Walshe's murder trial set to begin with jury selection on November 18 in Norfolk Superior Court.
Key cellphone evidence tied to the case of Ana Walshe's disappearance remains preserved for defense review.
Judge Diane Freniere ordered the final pre-trial conference for November 17, aiming to conclude by Christmas.

title: Star Market over the Mass. Pike reopens after asbestos scare
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Star Market over the Mass. Pike reopened after a three-day closure due to an asbestos scare.
Asbestos was found to be contained in a stockroom; air and surface tests showed no risk to shoppers.
The MassDEP is overseeing asbestos abatement efforts, ensuring work in the stockroom remains contained.
